scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Chiniquy collection, which the Library bought from John Howell, the San Francisco bookseller, in 1954, adds to the extensive literature regarding Charles Paschal Telespore Chiniquy, including his connections, real and imaginary, with Abraham Lincoln.

Chiniquy (1809-1899), ordained in Quebec in 1833, settled in Illinois in 1851, and laid the foundations for several French-Canadian communities in Kankakee County. In 1856, after Chiniquy had been sued for slander by Peter Spink and Spink had obtained a change of venue to the Champaign County Circuit Court, Lincoln arranged for the parties to settle the suit. Leaving the Catholic Church after a number of disputes with the hierarchy and with many others, Chiniquy wrote Fifty Years in the Church of Rome (1885), in which he charges that the Jesuits had conspired to murder Lincoln.
This collection includes thirteen letters, 1878-1895, from Chiniquy to Edwin A. Sherman of San Francisco, commander of the Lincoln Grand Guard of Honor, who similarly attacked the Catholic church.
In addition, it includes letters to Sherman from John Carroll Power, director of the Lincoln Guard of Honor and custodian of the Lincoln Tomb.

Finally, it includes letters to Sherman regarding his book, The Engineer Corps of Hell; or, Rome's Sappers and Miners Containing the Tactics of the "Militia of the Pope," or the Secret Manual of the Jesuits, and Other Matter Intensely Interesting, Especially to the Freemasons and Lovers of Civil and Religious Liberty... (1883); Chiniquy's signed promise to protect that volume; a circular dedicating Fifty Years in the Church of Rome to Sherman; and an undated broadside against Republican presidentidal candidate, James G. Blaine.

Stacy Pratt McDermott summarizes Spink v. Chiniquy in Lincoln Legal Briefs, 77:3-6 (Jan.-Mar. 2006). More detailed is Joseph George, Jr., "The Lincoln Writings of Charles P. T. Chiniquy," Journal of the Illinois State Historical Society, 69:1 (Feb. 1976), 17-25. For the fullest discussion of the context of Chiniquy's turbulent life, see Caroline B. Brettell, Following Father Chiniquy: Immigration, Religious Schism, and Social Change in Nineteenth-Century Illinois (Carbondale: Southern Illinois University Press, 2015). Apparently missing from this literature is a lenghty entry in The United States Biographical Dictionary...Illinois Volume (1876) 718-23, written by Chiniqy himself, according to his first letter to Sherman.
